text:
It’s Professor Dave, I wanna tell you about
the Pythagorean Theorem.

There is one more very important theorem we
need to discuss regarding triangles.

While some theorems seem pretty obvious, there
is a theorem relating the side lengths of
a right triangle that is not so obvious.

This theorem is called the Pythagorean theorem,
named for Pythagoras himself, even though

the theorem was likely discovered prior to
Ancient Greece.

Nevertheless it was an impressive feat of
logic, and one of the most famous mathematical
relationships, so let’s go over it now.

In a right triangle, there is one ninety degree
angle, by definition.

The two sides that meet to form this right
angle are called the legs of the triangle,

and the third side, the one opposite the right
angle, is called the hypotenuse.

This theorem states that the sum of the squares
of the legs of a right triangle is equal to
the square of the hypotenuse.

This is represented by the equation A squared
plus B squared equals C squared, where A and
B are the legs, and C is the hypotenuse.

This means that given any two sides of a right
triangle, we can calculate the third.

For example, let’s say the legs have lengths
of five and twelve.

We just plug these in as A and B, square them,
and we get twenty-five plus one hundred forty
four, which is one hundred sixty nine.

Since this is equal to C squared, we have
to take the square root of both sides.

This gives us plus or minus thirteen for C.
Since this is not algebra but rather geometry,

and we are looking at shapes, we can throw
away the negative value, because it doesn’t

make sense for a side length to be negative,
so we can definitively say that this hypotenuse
has a length of thirteen.

Likewise, we could know the hypotenuse and
one leg, and calculate the other leg.
Say we have five and nine.

That means five squared plus B squared equals
nine squared.

Twenty-five plus B squared equals eighty-one,
B squared equals fifty-six, and B must be

root fifty six, which can be simplified to
root four times root fourteen, or two root
fourteen.

The lengths won’t always be neat and tidy
integers, so we’d better get used to this.

Sometimes we do algebra using the pythagorean
theorem.

Say the legs of a right triangle are equal
to X and four root three, while the hypotenuse
is equal to two X.
What are all the side lengths?

Well we can plug these terms into the theorem
just like we would any numbers.

After squaring everything, on the left we
have X squared, plus four squared is sixteen

times root three squared which is three, giving
us forty-eight.

On the right, two X quantity squared is four
X squared.

We subtract X squared, divide by three, and
take the square root.

Once again, although we technically get plus
and minus four, negative four doesn’t make
any sense here, so X must be four.
That makes the missing sides four and eight.

This theorem is incredibly useful and ubiquitous
in math.
So how was it derived?

How can we know for sure that this relationship
between the sides of a right triangle is true?

A satisfactory proof will require the ability
to calculate the area of certain shapes, so

I promise we will return to this question
very soon.
For now, let’s check comprehension.
